thread.title_full: Yes, That's Jewish Folk Music You're Hearing—in Mexico - Wall Street Journal

title: Yes, That's Jewish Folk Music You're Hearing—in Mexico - Wall Street Journal
text:
A-hed Yes, That’s Jewish Folk Music You’re Hearing—in Mexico The street performer ‘El Maestro’ grew up in a small town and is not Jewish, but spends his days entertaining tourists with traditional klezmer songs he learned on the Internet; ‘a small summary of all of life’ Juan “El Maestro” Pérez (center, right) and his band, El Coloectivo Klezmorino, perform traditional klezmer music on the streets of Puebla, Mexico. Photo: Robbie Whelan/The Wall Street Journal By Biography Robbie Whelan Updated Jan. 8, 2017 4:28 p.m. ET 
PUEBLA, Mexico—On most days, weather permitting, Juan “El Maestro” Pérez packs up his clarinet and his accordion and descends to the city’s main plaza to play music for tips from tourists. 
But El Maestro doesn’t look or sound like other street musicians here in Puebla—a Spanish colonial city known for its ornate pottery and dozens of churches—who mostly play mariachi guitars and sing romantic Mexican songs. 
Instead, Mr. Pérez... To Read the Full Story, Subscribe or Sign In Most Popular Videos
